thoughts.a: Input and output grids are the same sizes. They're both mostly black background color, with some scattered tiles of blue and aqua. The different sets of aqua tiles are acting as the corners of a bounding box, And inside each bounding box, there is the start of a pattern of blue tiles. It seems like in the output grid, This blue pattern has been completed by moving some of the scattered blue tiles that are external of the aqua bounding boxes into the aqua bounding boxes, specifically in such a way to produce a symmetry inside each of the aqua bounding box. So the hypothesis is the following. Input grid will be a mostly black background color, and will contain some color reducing corners of a bounding box. Each of these bounding boxes will contain a different color of tiles. The input grid will also contain a scattered number of these other colored tiles. Yo construct the output grid is to use these tiles as building blocks to add into the different bounding box sections to create a mirrored or symmetric object inside the bounding box. In this specific input-output pair, each of the external blue building block objects can be used multiple times. The output grid additionally does not contain these external building blocks anymore. They are cleared from the output grid.
thoughts.b: Input and output grids are again the same sizes as expected. They're both mostly black background color. In this case, the bounding box objects are denoted by red with the internal shapes denoted by blue. for each of the three bounding box objects, We need to construct a symmetric pattern. of the blue tiles inside of them. Note that the mirror symmetry that is exhibited is parallel to the shorter edge of the rectangular bounding box. So if we identify which side is the longer edge of each individual bounding box object, we can basically fold that bounding box's edge in half to produce the mirror symmetry needed in the interior. This is Sort of a shortcut method to get to the output grid. I think the intended purpose is to use the blue external pieces as building blocks. Because the output grid no longer contains these external blue pieces, and because in the output grid the internal parts of the red bounding boxes are symmetric along the longest edge of each red bounding box, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.c: The input grid contains through bounding boxes. In this case, they are colored green. The interior shapes are again blue with scattered exterior blue building blocks. The background color is black. According to the hypothesis, for each identified bounding box we need to construct a symmetric blue shape in the interior of the bounding box. In order to identify the axis of symmetry, we need to inspect the longest edge of each bounding box. In this pair, for example, the top bounding box is taller than it is wide. Therefore, the symmetry will be along this tall edge. So we need to fold it vertically on top of itself and imagine where these mirrored blue shapes would appear. We can construct it with the blue exterior building blocks. The other green bounding box in the bottom right corner has a longer edge horizontally. Therefore, we need to fold the shape left to right in order to imagine what the blue interior will look like. See in the output grid that the exterior blue bounding boxes are now gone and it's just replaced with black background color. Additionally, because the interior of the output grid's green bounding boxes are symmmetric as expected, the hypothesis holds.
thoughts.d: We apply the hypothesis here. Input grid consists of a black color background and a variety of yellow bounding box. In this case, four. Inside of each of the bounding boxes there is some blue shape on one half of the bounding box According to the hypothesis, to construct the output grid, we need to construct a symmetric version of the interior of the blue shapes in each of the yellow bounding boxes. To identify the axis of symmetry, we need to first identify the longer edge of each of the yellow bounding boxes. you can then imagine folding either left to right or top down these bounding boxes. When we do so, the interior blue shapes should align on top of each other, exhibiting symmetry along one axis in each of the bounding boxes. Remember that the output grid should contain no scattered exterior blue building blocks that are present in the input grid.
